before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"3acsh","text":"On the day of extraction: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"evbpf","text":"- Set water bath to 65°C (large enough for one 50-ml tube per sample)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e0j04","text":"- Chill isopropanol to -20°C (around 2.5 ml per sample)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"far5o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4ppi5","text":"Recent advances in long-read sequencing technologies have enabled the complete assembly of eukaryotic genomes from telomere to telomere by allowing repeated regions to be fully sequenced and assembled, thus filling the gaps left by previous short-read sequencing methods. Furthermore, long-read sequencing can also help characterizing structural variants, with applications in the fields of genome evolution or cancer genomics. For many organisms, the main bottleneck is to develop robust methods to obtain high-molecular-weight (HMW) DNA for whole genome sequencing purposes. We developed an optimized protocol to extract DNA suitable for long-read sequencing from the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, based on CTAB/phenol extraction followed by a size selection step for long DNA molecules. We provide validation results for the extraction protocol, as well as statistics obtained with Oxford Nanopore Technologies sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":693,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"91fbp","text":"- This protocol aims at extracting high-molecular-weight DNA molecules with maximal removal of contaminants. Both parameters are indeed crucial to take full advantage of long-read sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jll8","text":"- This protocol was developed for the microalga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, but might be adapted to other algae and land plants.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ktip","text":"- This protocol is relatively simple and short, however, for basic molecular biology (PCR, cloning of small fragments, etc.), simpler protocols may be preferred (e.g. www.chlamycollection.org/methods/).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":167,"length":33}],"data":{}},{"key":"ccoqm","text":"- The extraction steps rely mostly on home-made solutions. Purification and size selection uses commercial reagents, the composition of which is unknown to us.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"127AFE08962C11ECB46F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"www.chlamycollection.org/methods"}}}}

To avoid traces of phenol, do not attempt to transfer more than three quarters of the aqueous phase.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
